SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 6.
:box:Kellan blew her whistle to try to divert the arguing and declared that practice was over.
What does the word d͟i͟v͟e͟r͟t mean?

A.Choice: Draw attention away from

B.Choice: Keep energy focused on

D.Choice: Send a clear message about

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: Which statement best describes Kellan and Coach Williams?

A.Choice: They enjoy coaching beginner soccer teams.

B.Choice: They think their jobs are challenging.

C.Choice: They know how to motivate others.

D.Choice: They like to offer coaching tips.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 11.
:box:The players reminded her of Fourth of July fireworks, exploding in a hundred different directions.
At the first practice under Kellan, the players seem most like “Fourth of July fireworks” because they

A.Choice: are interested in art rather than athletics.

B.Choice: want attention rather than achievement.

D.Choice: act separately rather than together.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: Why are the players “sitting up taller and smiling” in paragraph 14?

A.Choice: They believe in their importance.

B.Choice: They know they will have fun.

D.Choice: They know they will win games.

SubTopics: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which paragraph reveals that coaching the Falcons embarrasses Kellan?

A.Choice: Paragraph 7

B.Choice: Paragraph 8

D.Choice: Paragraph 10

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: Which idea does Dominique's daisy chain come to represent in the passage?

A.Choice: The spirit of winning

B.Choice: The power of teamwork

D.Choice: The purpose of friendship

SubTopics: Analyze how differences in the points of view of the characters and the audience or reader (e.g., created through the use of dramatic irony) create such effects as suspense or humor.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 10.
:box:Kellan then raised her head and, with renewed confidence, quickened her pace enough that Luis had to run to catch up to her.
The author uses this sentence most likely to illustrate that Kellan is

A.Choice: physically fit.

B.Choice: impatient with Luis.

D.Choice: angry at Luis.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.
Content: The author's most likely purpose for writing this article was to

A.Choice: explain a way to safely lose weight.

B.Choice: recommend certain foods over others.

C.Choice: give readers a basic understanding of the calorie.

D.Choice: help readers determine their ideal caloric intakes.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 1.
:box:Without sufficient calories in our bodies, our hearts would cease to pump, our muscles would deteriorate, and our brains would not be able to process information.
What does the word d͟e͟t͟e͟r͟i͟o͟r͟a͟t͟e mean?

A.Choice: Cause pain

B.Choice: Become weak

D.Choice: Use available nourishment

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.
Content: Why does the author define “'calorie'” in the second sentence of paragraph 1?

A.Choice: To explain how water is affected by calories

B.Choice: To describe the many uses of calories

C.Choice: To establish the fact that food contains calories

D.Choice: To promote a discussion about calories

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced.
Content: What is the author's underlying argument in the article?

A.Choice: Meals with many calories are unhealthy.

B.Choice: Each teenager has different nutritional needs.

C.Choice: People should try to develop healthy eating habits.

D.Choice: Active people can eat more than those who avoid exercise.

SubTopics: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: According to the article, serving size is most closely related to

A.Choice: identifying foods high in calories.

B.Choice: obtaining energy from calories.

D.Choice: exercising to burn calories.

SubTopics: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Based on paragraph 7, readers can conclude that people today

A.Choice: eat out more than they did many years ago.

B.Choice: understand the nutritional value of calories.

D.Choice: eat more than they did many years ago.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.
Content: The author keeps the language of the article from becoming too technical by

A.Choice: using many examples.

B.Choice: defining key terms.

D.Choice: discussing caloric intake.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 7.
:box:Think of the total number of calories a person takes in when devouring an entire bag of potato chips!
Based on paragraph 7, the word d͟e͟v͟o͟u͟r͟i͟n͟g suggests eating that is

A.Choice: messy.

B.Choice: uncontrolled.

D.Choice: enjoyable.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which statement from the article supports the idea that people who want to avoid gaining weight must pay attention to how they eat?

A.Choice: “Those additional 500 calories can come from merely eating several handfuls of nuts or sampling a few extra cookies.” (paragraph 3)

B.Choice: “An excess of fat calories can have serious negative health effects.” (paragraph 5)

C.Choice: “Registered dieticians can certainly help individuals learn what caloric intake is right for them.” (paragraph 6)

D.Choice: “Since 1960, our plates and bowls have grown by 36 percent.” (paragraph 7)

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: Which word best describes the speaker's attitude toward the socks?

A.Choice: Generous

B.Choice: Indecisive

D.Choice: Critical

SubTopics: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Based on lines 1–7, what can readers infer?

A.Choice: Sheep wool is softer than rabbit fur.

B.Choice: Maru Mori's hands are old and worn.

C.Choice: Hand-knit socks are more durable than manufactured socks.

D.Choice: Maru Mori used wool from her sheep for the socks.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: What happens when the speaker first wears the new socks?

A.Choice: The speaker's feet feel much warmer.

B.Choice: The speaker imagines the socks are blackbirds or cannons.

C.Choice: The speaker's feet actually turn into fish.

D.Choice: The speaker feels silly wearing the socks.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast the structure of two or more texts and analyze how the differing structure of each text contributes to its meaning and style.
Content: How does the poet emphasize that the socks are a pair?

A.Choice: Rhyme: words that have final syllables sounding alike

B.Choice: Metaphor: comparing one person or item to another

C.Choice: Repetition: the same word or word pattern over and over

D.Choice: Alliteration: repeating the beginning sounds of words

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text, including those by and about Minnesota American Indians, and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which sentence best expresses the main idea of the poem?

A.Choice: Cost is unimportant when people give gifts.

B.Choice: The best things in life cost nothing.

C.Choice: Clothes should look unusual and amazing.

D.Choice: People enjoy ordinary items for their comfort and beauty.

SubTopics: Analyze how differences in the points of view of the characters and the audience or reader (e.g., created through the use of dramatic irony) create such effects as suspense or humor.
Content: The poet most likely assumes readers

A.Choice: know what hand-knit, woolen socks are like.

B.Choice: use socks every day without appreciating them.

C.Choice: want to own socks like the pair described in the poem.

D.Choice: share his enthusiasm for a good pair of socks.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: In the poem, who is the speaker most like?

A.Choice: “explorers / in the jungle” who consume their prey (lines 64–70)

B.Choice: “schoolboys” who “keep / fireflies” (lines 50–52)

D.Choice: “firemen” who are “unworthy / of that embroidered / fire” (lines 40–43)

SubTopics: Analyze how differences in the points of view of the characters and the audience or reader (e.g., created through the use of dramatic irony) create such effects as suspense or humor.
Content: What does the poet most likely want readers to know?

A.Choice: The importance of giving valuable items as gifts

B.Choice: People should use rather than save treasured items

C.Choice: The importance of treasuring gifts based on who gives them

D.Choice: People should value objects based on their appearance

SubTopics: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: According to the article, today's rapid growth of games is a result of

A.Choice: advancing technology in electronic devices.

B.Choice: increasing the challenges for youth in sports.

D.Choice: changing the culture of international competitions.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: Based on paragraph 6, the phrase “straddle the thin line” suggests a player's

A.Choice: tendency to panic.

B.Choice: need for balance between pace and difficulty.

D.Choice: desire for strength over speed.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which sentence states the main idea of paragraph 8?

A.Choice: Games help us to view ourselves as individuals.

B.Choice: Games allow us to see ourselves as explorers.

C.Choice: Games allow us to understand each other.

D.Choice: Games help us to compete better against each other.

SubTopics: Analyze how a text makes connections among and distinctions between individuals, ideas, or events (e.g., through comparisons, analogies, or categories).
Content: Based on “The Game that Taught a Theory,” Elizabeth Magie was most likely a person with

A.Choice: ambitions for wealth.

B.Choice: a selfish attitude.

D.Choice: a sense of fairness.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.
Content: What is the main purpose of the opening paragraph of “The Game that Taught a Theory”?

A.Choice: To instruct readers on the history of board games

B.Choice: To offer readers background information about Monopoly

C.Choice: To educate readers about the historical roots of Monopoly

D.Choice: To enlighten readers with the basic principles of economics

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.
Content: Based on paragraph 15, with which statement would the author most likely agree?

A.Choice: Henry George thought people should live simply.

B.Choice: Elizabeth Magie's game was more meaningful than Monopoly.

C.Choice: Henry George's economic theories were superior to other theories.

D.Choice: Elizabeth Magie thought the company that purchased Monopoly was greedy.

SubTopics: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: According to paragraph 14, over time Monopoly players wanted

A.Choice: more fun.

B.Choice: different games.

D.Choice: different theories.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 15.
:box:George's economic theories became less popular over time. However, the game continued evolving until 1935, when a version called “Monopoly” was bought by a large game company.
In this quotation, what does e͟v͟o͟l͟v͟i͟n͟g mean?

A.Choice: Constantly developing

B.Choice: Failing attempts

D.Choice: Finally ending

SubTopics: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Paragraph 4 of “Got Game?” states, “Games are about uncertainty.” In “The Game that Taught a Theory,” which part of Elizabeth Magie's game represents the most uncertainty?

A.Choice: Playing with a particular game piece

B.Choice: Paying $180 to buy a game property

C.Choice: Earning $100 for going around the game board

D.Choice: Landing on a particular spot on the game board
